author: JimboRR

description.text:
A simple coffee tamper in 52mm for my espresso machine.  
Your can modify the width of the object. It is available as OpenSCAD file.   
It fits nicely in the palm of the hand and one can bring up a good pressure for tampering the coffee.   
Due the fact the the "coffee contact" is on the foot where the part is on the print bed. That contact area is very flat and "closed". So no "coffee dirt" enter the part. I use my tamperer since 3 weeks on a daily base and it is still shiny.  
Actually this was my first useful item printed on my 3D printer.  
Site note: the wiggles on the part came from a "moving" z-Motor. I printed the part before i improved my printer on that, see my part "New z-Motor-Holder".  
Have a nice macchiato in the morning!

Printed in PLA (white with 210 degree Celsius) on a heated print bed (50 degree Celsius).  
With 3 outer walls and 25% infill (Honeycomb).

print_settings.Notes:: You will need two of leg part 1 then mirror the design and print two more. for a total of 4 leg part 1.

description.text:
update 5/16/2016

There is a display of the robots at the Contemporary Art Museum of St. Louis. http://camstl.org/ This was a very rewarding class that highlighted 3D printed robotics in Art. Go ahead build yourself a museum class robot.

This is a custom robot made for a a one time workshop for high school art students though a program found here. http://camstl.org/programs/youth-teen-programs/nan/

During the workshop we divided roughly 20 students up into 4 groups were each group built a walking robot.

Not shown is that a moisture sensor is attached to analog port 0 on the Light Blue bean.

Here is a Drop box link to the workshops build instruction and the program. The program is a bit rough but it will be a great starting point.

https://www.dropbox.com/sh/85v7aavc3psypyl/AACJ7jt0dUC9zp7bbGm1b40Ba?dl=0

The robots are programmed to move towards light and to be an extension of the plant itself. They do this by moving towards sunlight and beeping when the moisture of the plant is low. This allows the robot to warn you when the plant needs water while keeping the plant in the sunlight longer than normal potted plant can. These robots are hexapod robots. For example, hexapod robots can step over various obstacles, like a book, that a wheeled robot can not.

The light sensor should be facing angled towards the front of the robot with a clear line of sight to work correctly

Parts list:

All printed parts
3x Hitec HS-422 Servos
1x Light blue Bean controller
18 M3 x 11 screws
1x CDS photoresistor
2x 220 ohm resistors
1x 1k ohm resistor
1x 22 uf capacitor
2x LED any color
1x Octopus Soil Moisture Sensor
1x misc wires
1x Great Planes Threaded 2-56 Ball Link Set (Set of 6)
1x small plant/soil
8x 10-24 x 3/4 inch or metric equivalent
3x 10-24 x 2 inch or metric equivalent
1x 3.3 volt drop out regulator or DC-DC drop in replacement, part number LD1117v33c
1x buzzer 3.3 volt or 5 volt
1x 4 AA battery holder
4x AA batteries (rechargeable if possible)
1x 1/4 scrap plastic, you will need to laser cut to base panels the 133 mm wide and 230 mm long The top base plate needs a cutout for the plant pot that measures 68 mm in diameter.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple White

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 - .18

Infill:

15-20

Notes:

All parts can be printed support free \o/

Some holes will need to be drilled out. The center legs will need to be drilled out to mach the center spar.

You will need two of leg part 1 then mirror the design and print two more. for a total of 4 leg part 1.

One mistake after another

The design was broken out into sections, I first designed the micro controller case and found it to be to small or large after printing so I made changes to the design and printed again. This was the case with all the parts. Trial and error - repeat. I find that breaking a project up into multiple sections help you push the overall design forward.

The robot was designed with a few paper sketches then I did a mock up in Google sketch up. From there I designed each part individuality in Autodesk Fusion 360. My overall favorite part is the plant pot as it shows beauty can be hidden in many places even a design hidden under a plant pot.

Project: Walking plants

Project Name: Walking robotic plants

Overview & Background: The students will help create a truly unique walking robot. You will not only learn about 3D printing and robotics. There is even some art in the mix.

Objectives:

  • 3D printing - Teach core lessons in using a 3D printer and its future impact on the world
  • Electronics - A outline of the circuit included and why what each component does.
  • Building a robot - Assembly of the robot to teach tool usage and teamwork. Its best to divide students in a 4-5 person groups each with there own (kit)
  • Plant biology - How do plants grow and talk about the importance of both sun and water is to a plants overall health.
  • C++ - A brief description of programming is all that is needed, the program is already provided in the dropbox link below. Also it is open for changes including extending the time between when the robots move. I suggest a minute for demonstrations and a hour for long term use of the robot.
  • Art - Robotics and electronics can be a rewarding expression of the arts.

Audiences: Skill level would be 9th grade and higher

Subjects: Science, Math, STEM

Skills Learned (Standards): Skills will be a basic understanding of C++ programming as it relates to robotics, Learning the biology of plants needs and the impact we have on the environment. This includes using biodegradable filament to produce a large portion of the robot.

Lesson/Activity: A full step by step build is provided to get started. Please use: https://www.dropbox.com/sh/85v7aavc3psypyl/AACJ7jt0dUC9zp7bbGm1b40Ba?dl=0

Duration: Build time approx 3 hours however this may seem rushed I would set a week aside so 5-7 hours to complete the build and further skills in programming and 3D printing.

Preparation: A 3D printer, soldering iron, and basic hand tools will be needed. The teacher may wish to print most items before the class takes place. Also the micro controller can be swapped for a standard Arduino if needed with only minor software changes.

References:

Makerbot in the classroom:
http://pages.makerbot.com/download-makerbot-in-the-classroom.html?utm_source=leaden&utm_medium=website&utm_campaign=makerbot-in-the-classroom-download

The micro controller starter guide:
https://punchthrough.com/bean/guides/getting-started/intro/

My personal website for even more projects to fuel creativity.
http://secondrobotics.com/

Rubric & Assessment: Grading of the project can be in stages, 5-10 points each with a bonus 20 points to those who modify large sections of the code. I.E if the robot is able to power on and walk, Also how fast can the robot go. Is it able to step over large objects, Is the overall wiring clean.

Handouts & Assets: Both the code, a brief summery of the class and step by step build instructions are provided in the following link. https://www.dropbox.com/sh/85v7aavc3psypyl/AACJ7jt0dUC9zp7bbGm1b40Ba?dl=0

This is a train car for wooden track train sets with pegs on top for connecting Lego-style bricks. This allows you to make your own custom train cars.
It is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11671 by sconine, with steel axles and magnet couplers.
For the couplers, it uses acorn nuts on the ends with magnets behind them for coupling to other cars.
The wheels and body were made with OpenSCAD, so they can be modified as needed to fit different hardware or to get a good fit with the pegs.
There is also an assembly fixture which was made in Alibre Design, as I had trouble doing it with OpenSCAD. The fixture helps with gluing the wheels onto the axles and getting them straight. It is especially handy if you are going to use cyanoacrylate which sets quickly.
NOTE: The STL files are nominal size. I had to scale the body up by 1.5% to account for shrinkage and get the pegs to align.

You will need to print (1) body and (4) wheels for each car. For each car you will also need:
(2) #6-32 steel acorn nuts
(2) 8mm x 3mm rare earth magents
(2) 1/8" steel rods cut to 27mm length.
epoxy or CY glue. You may also want to print the assembly fixture to help get the wheels straight. Put a magnet onto the back of each acorn nut. Make sure the acorn nuts will stick to each other. If not, turn one magnet around.
Dry fit the magnets and acorn nuts into each end of the body to make sure they go in straight. Then, glue them in.
Drill the two axle holes out to 9/64" so the axles will turn freely in them. Drill the holes in the wheels out to 1/8". Put the axles through the body and glue the wheels on with the hubs facing inwards. The 27mm axles should be flush with the outer faces of the wheels. The inside spacing between the wheels should be 23mm.
If you are using the fixture, you can set the body and wheels in place first, and then push the axles through everything, gluing the tips.

I don't know much about 3d printing so if anyone wanted to print this they might have to modify it first...

title: Beginner Friendly Raspberry Pi Zero Game System.

description.text:
Very easy Raspberry Pi Zero System for Beginners.
Just need Basic Solder skills and a hot glue gun to help hold parts in place.
I like to do wiring in a very easy to read setup so everyone can try it.
The PS3 controller I used I have taken out the battery to help with any power drain issues and it works fine.
No Sound at the moment from the pi zero but once I figure out a easy way to hook into it I will update the designs.
I made all the holes to fit with M3 type screws.
The battery I removed from a broken tablet, but you can use what ever fits just check broken electronics or local electronics stores and to hold it in place I just used strong double sided tape from the dollar store.
The screen was purchased here
http://www.ebay.ca/itm/3-5-Inch-TFT-LCD-Car-Rear-View-Monitor-Color-Screen-DVD-VCR-For-Backup-Camera-/251946543362
I got really lucky in that is actually has a 3.3v spot to wire in so my battery works great with it.
The Charger and 5v booster can be purchased here. http://www.aliexpress.com/item/0-9V-5V-600MA-USB-Output-charger-Mini-DC-DC-Boost-Converter-TP4056-1A-Lipo-Battery/2038845625.html
I snipped off the USB connector to make it more flush.
For the connectors I had previously bought this wiring kit
http://www.ebay.ca/itm/9PCS-70CM-2P-3P-4P-RepRap-3D-Printer-Ramps-1-4-Basic-Wiring-jumper-cable-Kit-/171274570090?hash=item27e0c2896a:g:-QMAAOxy039TLQZr but if you have a local electronics store then they would have it as well as the 90 degree pins for the board.
If you can't find any then wiring directly to the board and battery will work just as well.
The switch I bought locally but I believe this is the same one.
http://www.ebay.ca/itm/5Pcs-Small-Size-2Pin-Black-Rocker-Switch-6A-250V-ON-OFF-SPST-KCD1-101-/171329602644?hash=item27e40a4454:g:~ZwAAOxynwlTc2iK
I found a go pro mount model and mixed it into the design so a 5mm bolt works that's about 35-40mm long.
The controller clip is from bernabap http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43977 just changed it to be in sections and easier to print.
Can purchase a mini OTG connector from here, https://www.adafruit.com/product/2910 , mine looks different since I purchased it awhile ago.
The case mounts you can just poke through the holes with a screwdriver, I found it helps to keep holes from drooping if I add a printed section between.

RepRap

Prusa i3 Rework

description.text:
Two of these assemblies fit on either side of a Filament reel. A length of M8 threaded rod slides into the holes in the bearings and rests on the Filament Spool Brackets published here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1565465.
Almost frictionless compared with the original spool holder, eliminating one of the causes of Z-axis issues.

Apart from 2 copies of the end disc and the spool adaptor, you need 2 22x7x8mm bearings (very common size), 6 M3 x 10mm machine screws, a length of M8 threaded rod, 2 nuts and washers.

print_settings.Notes:: Also, the model works best when scaled to 45-50%

description.text:
This hovercar was part of a project assigned with the title "make something cool." It is not designed to float on a cushion of air like real hovercars, but it instead floats on a plastic wrap bubble powered with balloons.
Educationally, this hovercar can provide lessons in math and physics, in the context of calculating thrust. Having taken multiple boring physics classes where teachers try and explain thrust with whiteboard drawings, I found this model useful for understanding thrust to weight ratios as well as friction.

SCALE THE MODEL TO 40-50% TO PRINT IT!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

7%

Notes:

7% is realistically the lowest possible infill. If you think your printer can handle lower than that, you can try, but too low infill results in a generally fragile part.

Also, the model works best when scaled to 45-50%

Materials for assembling the model

Your model
Four regular sized balloons
LOW TEMP hot glue gun
HIGH TEMP hot glue gun
Several rubber bands
A plastic wrap rectangle that is 1-2 inches larger than the base of your model

Assembling the model

After cleaning rafts and supports off of your model, blow through each of the pipes coming off the top to check that air will pass through them. If air does not pass through the back hole in the model, I recommend using a very small drill bit to widen the hole slightly.

Find or Purchase four balloons. Blow one up and test to make sure it can force air through each of the four pipes.

Using a LOW TEMP hot glue gun, glue the plastic wrap to the extruded parts in the bottom of the model. Once the glue dries, fold the plastic wrap up the sides of the model and use several rubber bands to secure. Using a HIGH TEMP hot glue gun, seal the rubber bands and plastic wrap onto the sides of the model so that the plastic wrap melts to the model.

Using the model

Inflate all four balloons to about half their maximum size.
Place them over the four pipes in the model
Attempt to release air to all four at the same time.
See how far your hovercar travels and experiment with it!

Onshape

Seriously, Onshape is the best thing that has ever happened to CAD. I designed this entire model on a Chromebook, exported it as a .stl and scaled it to be printed. The first prototype took about 30 minutes to design and 4 hours to print. Total active time for designing and assembling all prototypes and models was about 5 hours
My design file is available for copying and online editing here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/67d7ff391e984e69b71506af/w/bb9d024722bd4e3eb84d6db1/e/92ae0fce4afc41bf821eee7c

Project: Hovercar forces

Originally part of a project to "make something cool," this design demonstrates various necessary math, physics, and engineering skills.

Overview and background:
Using this design, kids possibly as young as third grade could start to understand how various forces interact. The main forces demonstrated with this 3d printable physics toy are friction and thrust. The thrust from the balloons must be great enough to overcome friction , which could be part of a simple lesson.

Objectives:
The goal of teaching a lesson with this design would be to show kids how physics can be fun, as well as a basic understanding of some forces.

Audiences:
This project would be best used during an elementary school science class. kids between 8 and 10 are my target audience for learning from this.

Relevant subjects:
Basic understanding of the idea that object move. This expands on that idea and starts to show why objects move: forces. A very basic understanding of algebra would also be useful.

Skills learned:
Students would obtain a basic understanding of forces, and, depending on their math level, they could work on more simple math.

Steps needed to complete this activity:
Once the hovercar is assembled (see post-printing for assembly instructions), students should be gathered around a table. All four balloons would be placed on the nozzles, and the hovercar should slowly move forward. The exact same procedure can be repeated on different surfaces. I provided a worksheet educators are free to use if they wish at
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jndj0z3MluNBHIgyEJIoTIhNnPlf-zCJxRcjzSVspx0/edit?usp=sharing

Duration:
Depending on the maturity of the students, this should take approximately 0.5-1 hours, approximately the amount of time spent on science during one day in an elementary school.

Preparation:
This experiment requires a pre-assembled hovercar as the only preparation. It takes four hours to print at the smallest size that works best. The assembly takes approximately a half hour after printing.

References:
I used a few formulas and calculations from physics classes, but otherwise this was my design

Handouts

Handouts

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1jndj0z3MluNBHIgyEJIoTIhNnPlf-zCJxRcjzSVspx0/
This is a possible worksheet for young students to fill out as they work.

description.text:
An easy, non-invasive light-weight shelf to put inside a window frame.

The uploaded STLs can be used with four 3/8in dowel rods. (which set me back $6.05 so easily the cheapest shelf i've ever installed)

NOTE: still working on getting the thread settings right to find the sweet spot of print-ability and strength
EDIT: finally found something that works pretty well, turns out it's very important to print the threaded rod piece at 100% infill. That piece has to be strong enough that you can drive it into the end cap with plyers without breaking it. I've found that after I used plyers to tighten them together all the way once or twice, they were broken in enough that I could work them pretty easily work them with my fingers, but they weren't so loose that they wouldn't be strong enough to put pressure on the wall to hold up the shelf.

This customizer takes a while to compile especially if you adjust the resolution to a higher value. The uploaded stls are made with a resolution of 50 which i find is much better than 24, but takes much longer to compile. I've provided a zip of openscad files that provide each individual piece so you can adjust each part as needed.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I recomend doing this with layer height between 0.1 and 0.2

Infill:

The DynamicCap and the DynamicExtension need a high infill percentage (30%-40%)

Notes:

Smaller layer heights will result in a smother turning screw, if you're having trouble getting the threaded rod to fit in the end cap, i suggest either bumping up the "extra_space" value in customizer or using a layer height less than 0.2

I really wanted this to be printable on my 5th Gen machine, and my end product is. But I also made a version on my Rep 2 with a 0.1 layer height, and they turned out lovely.

title: Air Raid Siren - hand crank version 2

description.text:
Remix of my own design. I had a lot of positive response so i desided to redesign it and use metal bearings to avoid friction problems i had with the 100% 3D printed version. Runs much smoother now!

To build this you need these metric [mm] bearings:
(amount x outer diameter / inner diameter / height - link)

  • 1 x 47/25/12 - SKF 6005-2Z
  • 4 x 16/5/5 - SKF 625-2Z

I also tried to design it with 3d printed bearings - But did not work that well. I could get these bearing in an industrial store in my town for around 35 €. The bearing are standard sizes - so you should get them easy.

Videos:

I uploaded two clips to youtube.

  • Printing Timelapse
  • Assembly and Test

Slicer note:

I used Simplify3D to slice all parts. If you print it with MakerWare the parts might not fit together - i found out that MakerWare does not care for the nozzle size. Thats why i had some space between every part on my preview version that was featered on thingiverse. I don't now how cura and other slicers work. You should test it with some small parts like GetrRad2A and GetrRad2B before you print bigger parts - they should fit together very tight.

In case you own a Makerbot Replicator but don't have Simplify3D - i added a .zip-archive that contains all sliced .x3g-files ready to print. There is also a README.txt if you have problems getting the bigger parts printed on your R2.

Designing:

I use basic AutoCAD to draw my 3D stuff because i use it a lot on my work. It took me about 200 hours to design this siren. I added the drawing file if you want to make changes.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Most parts can be printed with standard settings - No Raft, No Support.

Except of following changes:

  • Gehause3 - change filament color while printing to get the text highlighted
  • GetrRad2A+B - print it solid, needs to be strong
  • GetrRad4A+B - print it solid, needs to be strong
  • Kurbel1 - use brim to prevent warbing
  • Kurbel2 - print the top layers solid
  • Rotor3 - print it with high resolution (0.1 mm) and raft to get clean props
  • Schraube1 - print it 3 times
  • Schraube2 - print it 6 times
  • Schraube3 - use brim

If not every part fits after printing you may have to use some abrasive paper. 

Parts like the rotor should be sticked together.

comments.author: MlePh

comments.text:
Ok, finally received all my bearings, and did the assembly tonite. I have a couple of questions...
1-The very thin "sticks" at the top of the unit, like 1mm wide, do they do anything for the sound, or are they just for the looks? I have a few that broke and wonder if it will be a problem (I don't know yet because my whole assembly failed).
2-The 2 small gears... I believe that 1 of the 2 has the wrong file here. Both gears should have a tiny pin on both ends, to go into the small bearings. But 1 of the 2 gears has a flat, no hole to insert the pin, and no pin. That does not work when assembling, because the flat goes right against the bearing that is in the top piece written "make it loud" on it. Could you please verify that file?
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text: 1 - those sticks are for safety. If you build the siren with the handle on top your finger could get into the rotor. A friend of mine hurt herself on the first siren version... so i fixed it in this one
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text: well, the file is fine after all.  I assembled it wrong.  I don't have access to a CAD system at home, so I was guessing on how to assemble it.  When I went to work, I saw that I did something wrong.  Sorry about that, your files are fine.
comments.author: MlePh

comments.text: Hi MlePh, I got the thing done, but it doesn't quite work yet.  I realized that my 300$ printer might not be super super accurate.  It is really good, but, here we have a rotor that spins at a few thousand RPM inside a round cage, and i can see that neither the rotor nor the cage are perfectly round.  Fortunately, my cage is white and rotor black, so I spin it a few times, take it out, and i can see where it rubs.  Dremel to the rescue!  I got it pretty good, but now the handle broke... haha, I am not lucky so far.  What breaks the most though, are those little pins that go inside the small bearings.  Actually only 1 of the breaks, it probably has the most stress on it.  Fortunately, I am a CNC programmer, so I will make those little pins out of aluminum, and they won break anymore.  That might take a few weeks before i get that done, because customer's jobs come 1st of course.  I'll report back when I get the pins done.  Just wanted to let you know where I was with the project now.
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text: Sounds like you really had to try a lot of things! Hope it will rund with the CNC made pins! Have you already tried to print the pins with a brim and 100% infill?
comments.author: DarthBane

comments.text:
Yes, the pins are 100% infill, but they shear (1 of them, always the same one). Probably a small alignment issue between the 2 bearings (this gear has a bearing on both ends, so the 2 bearings need to be really in line. Maybe in my print they are not 100% in line).
For the pins, as the shop is pretty busy, I got another idea... I will print the pins with a hole in them, and insert a steel nail inside. It won't shear anymore... I should be able to try that soon, I'll let you know how it went!
comments.author: MlePh

comments.text:
Alright, here's another update:
The pins with the nails in them worked perfectly, now it does not shear and i can feel the whole thing turning "rounder". But, although now i can make it scream, it does not turn as fast as yours (in the video). So the sound is not quite that of a siren just yet, it is too "low" of a tone. I noticed that the main big gear which is connected to the handle had a play of about 3mm along its axis, so I printed a spacer to eliminate it. After that, there is no play, everything is looking good when turning slow. But I still can't turn as fast as you. It's like it reaches a maximum RPM and I can't crank any harder, it won't go faster. I look at it while turning, and the back of the unit, the housing itself, sort of bends with the handle turning. I think it is too thin and has too much flex in it (I use PETG), so the gears inside can't stay straight. Now this is starting to be a major operation!! I might make a new housing, thicker on the back, to avoid the bending... but... not sure when I'll get to it now. This would require a new handle too... I just can't make it work as is!! :(
If you have any idea from your experience, about why i can't turn it faster, let me know!!

title: vertical tail fin for the Blade 230s

description.text:
Replacement vertical tail fin for the Blade 230s. Carbon fiber/ABS (stronger, cheaper, and lighter). holes need to be enlarged to 5/64. i will fix this in the next release. cut 2mm carbon fiber rod to length glue in place. you can strengthen the joint by binding it with kevlar fishing line and ca glue. like a barber poll.

on "cf mod fin 2" i changed the design a bit added a lightning hole and enlarged the mounting holes. they are now just a little small than 5/64 but would work without drilling. drilling 5/64 makes them perfect.

author: gianniscarpino

description.text:
Hi All.
I decided to make a working 3d printable Terminator 1 Arm for all.
Wires pull springs in the hand pistons causing mechanically operated fingers to close.
Releasing tension causes the fingers to straighten.
I have uploaded the un-smoothed version for easier modification, excluding the wrist.
I printed each piece at a time, but you can try print it as I have supplied it.
Items labled with an X3 should be duplicated 3 times and X15 -15 times etc.
Tubing is quicker to find than to print, so I suggest making a trip to your nearest hardware
for tubing, shafts and screws, unless, like me, you have some lying around.
I also suggest that you print in ABS so you can solvent weld some of the parts or repair it easily if parts break. If you have any requests or questions, leave a comment and I will do my best to reply. I will be posting a making-of video on youtube soon. Visit www.antsinafrica.co.za for more info.
Have fun and enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25-50%

Notes:

Printed in ABS at .1mm resolution at 60mm per second.
Not all parts require support. Only minor support is needed for some finger parts.
I recommend printing a brim on all parts. A raft might not prove strong enough.

All parts were lightly sanded and brushed with ascetone before spraying.
It's not necessary, but I'm a perfectionist.
Some parts need to be solvent welded together or glued if PLA is used.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/P73LFqmXvRM" ></iframe>
A quick 10min video of me designing, printing and making the arm.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/lQHXYl0iPTw" ></iframe>
This is a response to a question/request by cyclone for a build video. Enjoy!

comments.text: Hello, i am trying to print with PLA but no success, i started with the finger index and got a weak part and the small details got broken. Any help?
comments.author: paulorcrs

comments.text:
Hi there! Sure.
I suggest you start by breaking each finger group into individual parts and print each part separately.
I grouped them to avoid confusion. Cura allowes you to do this, but I don't know about other slicers?
There are only really three ways layer bonding can fail:
1- incorrect extruder temperature 2- incorrect speed, 3- excessive time between layers (if speed is high).
Or just inferior filament.... So it's a balance, but working with each part at a time improves your chances of success.
It minimizes time between layers, so the layers have a better chance of melting together.
I hope this helps.

comments.text: Great work! Can you tell em more about your acetone brushing process? Last item I tried everything just got gloopy. What's the secret? Lots of acetone and cleaning the brush regularly?
comments.author: Isolt

comments.text:
Thanks! Sure, I use a very clean soft bristled brush with a wide head and work very quickly and lightly.
The trick is to coat the piece VERY quickly in ONE thin layer and then put it in the sun to dry for 5 mins.
No area should be covered twice unless the previous layer has dried properly. It WILL start melting quickly.
It's literally like - Grab part and brush, dip tip in acetone, brush brush brush, stick in the sun and leave. 1min or less.
You don't need much. You can wipe the brush on a paper towel to remove excess if the brush is picking up too much.
But the acetone should never run! Obviously this only works with ABS!
For best results - sand the part first to remove print lines, use a thin wide coverage brush & use clean acetone when brushing.
I hope this helps. If you get it right, it looks really good and seems to make the part stronger.
Have fun and good luck!

title: Y Endstop Holder For Back Rod For Prusa Mendel

description.text: By mounting my y endstop on the back rod, rather than on the y carriage rods, I was able to get another 5-10 mm of bed distance.

• Adjust SCAD switch_dist variable for the hole spacing for your y endstop switch.
    (the included STL is for a mechanical switch whose holes are 9mm apart)
  • Export and Print STL
  • Install on rear threaded rod with nylock nuts such that endstop touches lower Prusa bed.
    • Optional: uncomment the comments in front of the nut traps to print for use with non-nylock nuts. Thanks to triffid_hunter for uploading a parameterized endstop which was easy to modify.
    AFAIK this is the only parameterized endstop, the rest of ones on thingiverse are STLs.

description.text:
Libro-Struder 2 is essentially the original Libro-Struder, but with a built-in planetary gearbox. This lets you use a standard Nema 17 motor without having to use a stepping gearmotor. This thing is experimental, but shows promise!

Libro-Struder: The Libro-Struder design uses friction between a grooved inner gear and 11 outer gears push filament down an tube toward a hot-end. This type of extruder is unique because it does not require a hobbed wheel, and so can be assembled from mostly hardware store parts. The use of friction distributed over a large gear instead of pinching action between a small set of rollers lets this mechanism grip and push filament with high power and without slipping.

Yes

Resolution:

Low is fine

Infill:

50 to 100 %

Notes:

I recommend printing everything at 50% except for the object "Planetary Gears" which should be printed at 100% (solid plastic).

Cleaning up the orbital gearing

It is tricky to get it to run smoothly, have broken several sets of the planetary gears. It is important to make sure the pair of revolving planets are exactly opposite each other with respect to the center gear. You may also wish to sand the teeth or to use a jeweler's file to smooth the surfaces slightly. There is some natural taper to the gears that happens during printing. The box provides a nearly 60:1 advantage.

Wearing in the Gearbox

The planetary gearbox is a bit rough and may be too tight to run smoothly when first assembled. I recommend putting grease into the teeth of the internal gears and then turning the box with a cordless drill at high speed for 4-5 minutes. This will 'wear-in' the teeth of all of the gears involved, and will make everything run much more smoothly.

Cleaning up the Filament Groove in the Big Gear

Printing will leave some amount of support material in the groove around the big gear. This groove must be cleaned out and preferably sanded with the folded edge of sandpaper. If the groove is not clean or not quite deep enough, it will put too much pressure on the filament and may cause the motor to stall. The small gears that encircle the big gear are held on small spring arms, and the arms are quite a bit shorter & stiffer in the Libro-Struder version 2 than in the version 1. This may or may not be a design problem/limitation.
R&D continues!

description.text: This is tail of Chicken Robot.
customized with 3D Slash! Different orientation for how the cards are pulled out

From Kindergarten to High School, this is usable in classrooms! Whether it be for cutting out play dough, tracing geometrical figures or even making sugar cookies in FACS, this Universal Cut Out can be utilized in classrooms around the world!

Now, there's even a carrying case for all of your favorite cut outs!

Cut Outs

I just sketched my shape and used the "Offset Entities" function. I extruded that sketch. Next. I made another sketch on the same original plane and offset the previous sketch. Lastly, I extruded it in the opposite direction.

Carrying Case

I simply used my old shapes and extruded them as an extruded cut on a rectangular prism. Then, I sketched a two squares and extruded them up. I added a hole using an extruded cut of a circle. For the cover of the case, I just free drew it.

Universal Shape Cut Outs

These Cut outs serve as simple stepping stones to help younger children learn their shapes. Although these can be utilized in many situations, they were primarily made to let children realize the importance and real life applications of knowing their shapes.

Overview and Background

Primarily, these cut outs would be used to help young students learn their shapes. Need a fun and easy way for them to learn their shapes? Try a quick session with some cut-outs and some sugar cookie dough! They'll love it! These could also be used to trace geometrical figures.

Usage 1: Cookie Cutter

Objectives: To help add fun to a baking unit
Subject: Home-Ec./FACS
Skills Learned: This mainly adds fun to cookies, but it does encourage learning how to cook so you can have fun.

description.text:
I've recently ordered a TrekStor SurfTab Wintron 7" tablet plus a
Hama OTG Tablet Bag with Integrated Keyboard (meant for 7").
However the straps could not hold the tablet, so I've constructed these cornerpieces to literally fill the gaps.

You can add two rubber bands inbetween the diagonal cornerpieces.
Now I just need to find a way to map the special keys (the keyboard is not meant for Windows tablets)

Notes:

You need to print two of each - the Cornerpiece and the Cornerpiece with hole to protect the four edges of the tablet. The two holes are for the Micro USB and the Volume+ key.

If you prefer, you can also print the upper and lower part of the corner pieces separately and glue them together. Very easy for ABS using Acetone.

print_settings.Notes:: This project benefits from the accuracy of a high resolution print.  Although the plug seems to print adequately at .3mm the cap certainly did not.  Reducing the cap to .15 and setting the supports to high did the trick nicely.  If I design this again, I may lessen the thread count or better yet, design it to fit a regular pop bottle lid.  It is awfully fine and really doesn't need to be.

description.text: One major annoyance of mine is manufacturers creating a product that requires you to purchase consumables specifically designed for that product by them called "Vendor Lock-In". In my defiance of this practice this is my latest design. It is a Wet Floor Mop Hack (label removed to protect my innocence). Drill a 3/4" hole in the disposable tank. This particular popular brand which we will fictitiously name "spiffer" has a bottom thickness of 2mm which this was designed for. Any heavy plastic bottle should work well as long as it isn't more than that. Heat the plastic with a hair dryer to soften it just a bit, press fit the plug firmly into the hole and VOILA you've got a refillable tank which is much greener for the ecology not to mention cheaper on the pocket book.

Printer:

XYZ Pro

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

See Text

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

This project benefits from the accuracy of a high resolution print. Although the plug seems to print adequately at .3mm the cap certainly did not. Reducing the cap to .15 and setting the supports to high did the trick nicely. If I design this again, I may lessen the thread count or better yet, design it to fit a regular pop bottle lid. It is awfully fine and really doesn't need to be.

The end product is a tight fit into the plastic and seals pretty well but will leak with pressure put to the bottle. If you want it really sealed, you can put some silicon in the groove before assembly and come up with some sort of gasket from the cap. For our needs, it works perfectly.

comments.text: One last comment.  I left the "spiffer" in the corner and apparently the liquid feed system isn't very sophisticated and uses the injection of air to release the liquid.  Meaning, that over time, the contents of the bottle leaked out!  The fix for that is a bead of silicon around the edge where the body meets the bottle and a piece of gasket material in the cap to create an air-tight seal.

comments.text: You can also heat the "spiffer" stock bottles in hot water and remove the caps, with some effort. But then you don't get to use your printer, so....it's a toss up!

description.text: This is a vortex diode or Zobel diode, apply flow in one direction and it will pass fine(center port to side port), apply flow in another(side port to center port) and a vortex will be formed in the chamber increasing resistance to flow. For more info vortex type fluidic devices and fluidic devices in general see: http://www.tippettsfountains.com/fluidicsbasics.php?width=1920&height=919
Bolt both plates together using M5 bolts or print as one piece. Connect to other fluidic elements using  5/16" tubing.

description.text:
Too lazy to go to the store and buy 600 of them? If you have a 3D printer, you can now have your very own paperclip in less than two minutes!

This is a simple paperclip that prints really quickly. I designed these to hold together about 10 pages of paper, but you could probably hold more sheets together. It's been working fine, but just don't expect them to do everything a normal paperclip could do.

Feedback and ideas are appreciated. Also, since I only have Ultimaker printers, I would be interested in seeing how it prints on other machines. So show me how it came out with a make.

description.text:
The bar on the plastic latch plate for our screen door captures both the latch and the dead bolt. When it broke off, 3D printing seemed like a good alternative for repair. The resulting part isn't as strong as the original, and certainly isn't as temperature tolerant, but it was much easier than machining an aluminum replacement.

The FreeCAD file is included for modifications. Hopefully this is of some use to someone.

Update: One week installed, and going strong.

Update: As of 26 July, still in place and working well.

The screw mounts CANNOT be misaligned! check it yourself in a 3D software. You should check your X&Y steps.

If you have misaligning issues, it can come from slicing or X and Y step specially if you don't print them in the same orientation.
If i were you i'll redo some calibration test for X, Y and E steps.

comments.text:
Hello

Only one question - what do you use for lubricating these printed bearings?
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text:
hi mate.
Thanks for your feedback, I'm glad to hear that it works as good for you that it works for me.
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text:
Thanks.
It is still not working good for me because it is not installed :), but for now it looks very good and I think it will be nice improvement.
What holds the Y rods in there? Is it only the belt connecting both end blocks?
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
same setting than the original blocks for the Y axis, it's just plug-in, then as the Z axis are connected at the top and the bottom, Y rods are trapped and cannot move. Then the belt add a tension, but even without that belt the rods can't go anywhere.
Btw each time/when you set the blocks, don't forget to put the top block back before screwing/fiddling, it will help to get them perfectly aligned.
gl
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text: You mean before screwing the bearing blocks to the main end blocks?
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
that doesn't matter if you already screw them don't worry, but unscrew them a bit for fiddling, put them on the Z axis rods, put the top block back, them tigh the screw back checking if it go smoothly. Same thing with the screw lead and the treathen rod.
This step of fiddling is a bit long and exhausted, but once you'll do it, you'll never have to touch it again and all will go as whished.
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text: OK, thanks for this instructions :) I'll try to do it.
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
Do you think that Z-axis motor current correction is needed as thedayowl described in his end block instructions?
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:995185
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text:
it looks like you are missing steps, so yes you probably need to add some current.
Personnaly i changed my board recently to a ramps 1.4 ; and the first thing i do is to split the 2 Z axis cables. Since that, my Z axis stay at the same height on both sides.
Check if its missing steps 1 or on the 2 sides :
-if it's only one, you should do something about that shitty JST plug
-if it's both sides, then you need to add some current
comments.author: pitmetal

comments.text: It is strange that it was working better the previous print. One of your bed fixations which are 17mm and I am just measuring it - it is about 16.96mm...
comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
it can also be the screw for Z level that moved....0.04mm is not a big deal
about plate fixation, it's probably the most difficult upgrade i've done (much more difficult than Z axis). May be you'll get it working fine at first shot (i hope for you) but you will probably have to print several before to get the perfect setting.

comments.author: 1sPiRe

comments.text:
At a quick look it kind of threw me with the stripes :)
Looks great, it'll be interesting what king of wear rate you get with those bearings, did you do them in PLA or ABS? Your average English level is fine mate, probably better than mine :)
I already have chain link on my setup so I won't change it, but if I hear good things about those bearings I may give them a go when these other Linear bearings crap out. I was amazed how just adding another set of bearings really stiffened up the wobble on my machine, I assume you found the same, the wobble has just about gone?
comments.author: hughee

comments.text:
all printed in PLA. I printed the Printed-Linear-Bearings with slow perimeters and a bit hotter than i used to.
Once i set the two blocks on the main block (not before) i gently used a file to get a perfect alignement between them until i get a really strong and smooth slide on the Z-axis. (Always put back the top yellow frame when testing).
I never have to deal with linear ball bearing yet, until i get this printer. So i can't say if they are all like that or if those one are really bad quality : I unmount them and check how it slide on the axis, and it wasn't nice at all : noises, wobbles, gaps...so i put them away.
comments.author: hughee

comments.text:
I like cable chain, it makes my machine look like a real machine :) But it doesn't really make a lot of difference to the machine, just a personal preference.
Feedback is always appreciated, especially about newer things like plastic bearings, thanks again.

title: A squaring block for the MPCNC IE Edition

description.text:
This is a simple solution to achieve more rigidity and better squaring between the X and Y axis for Allted's MPCNC IE. I think it will work also for the normal version but I'm not sure.

A small wallet sized to hold credit cards.
Locks securely closed.
There are small bumps to grip the edges of the cards to prevent them from falling out.
Wallet and WalletClip can hold a stack of cards roughly 10mm thick.
WalletThick can hold a stack of cards roughly 14mm thick.
WalletClip has an integrated money clip on the outside.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in E-Sun PLA+.
Two perimeters with a 0.5mm nozzle.
Cooling fan enabled (definitely needed for the end of the print)
This prints as once piece.
The only difference between model A, B, and C is the distance between the bumps to hold the cards in place. Print one of the test fit models and try your cards in that to see which one grips them the best without bending them too much.
The test fit will apply to the WalletClip and the WalletThick files as the fit that is being tested is how well it can grip a single card.

You will need to apply a little force to break the hinge free.
For the WalletClip version, you will need to snap off the support for the clip.
I had some success sanding mine with various grits of sand paper and finishing off with a 600 grit wet sand to really smooth it out.

author: Simhopp

title: IGUS linear bearing hopup for the E3D BigBox

description.text:
--- NOTE --- Tolerances for IGUS bearing with orange should be good but i'm not done testing different materials.

I'm experimenting with the IGUS RJMP-01-08/RJ4JP-01-08 linear bearing as a hopup for the rather noisy and bad quality (at least mine was)LM8UU there was shipped with the BigBoxes.

This unfortunately means remixing the carriages for the x- and y-axis, since the current clamps will make the short IGUS bearings kink and bind up.

I'm pretty much done with the x-axis carriages, but i still have to do the y-axis carriages, while the z-axis should be plug and play.

Notes on the design and the chosen way of fixing the IGUS bearing: I have decided to use the recesses for fixing o-rings and from there it is just a press fit into the carriages. This way everything should be nice and centered and in theory it should also be a little sound dampening.

You can follow my progress here: https://forum.e3d-online.com/index.php?threads/project-whisper-igus-solid-polymer-bearing.1358/

Cheers.

P.S. Sorry about the orientation

title: Otto DIY build your own robot

description.text:
Who is Otto DIY?

An interactive robot that anyone can make!
Otto walks, dances, makes sounds and avoids obstacles

Is completely open source, Arduino compatible and 3D printable

Gather all the off the shelf parts that you'll need for this assembly.
If you don't have or is difficult to get the part you can just

buy our full kits!

Visit http://www.ottodiy.com/
NO SOLDERING REQUIRED!

List of parts:

  1. Arduino Nano;
  2. Arduino Nano Shield I/O Extension Board Expansion XD-212
  3. Mini usb cable.
  4. HC-SR04 Ultrasound sensor.
  5. Mini servo SG90 9g x4 (each one should come with 2 pointed screws and one small screw also arm keys to attach legs and feet).
  6. 5V Buzzer.
  7. Female to Female breadboard connectors cable 10cm x6.
  8. 4 AA Battery case
  9. 1.5V AA batteries x4.
  10. Phillips screwdriver. (important magnetized)
  11. Switch 8x8mm

And then you only need to 3D print 6 parts in total:

  1. 3D printed head.
  2. 3D printed body.
  3. 3D printed leg x2.
  4. 3D printed right foot.
  5. 3D printed left foot.

update feet and legs latest version, now no need high precision printer to have good assembly with motors just use the small plastic arm that comes with the servo motor SG90 to attach them.

you can change easily the size and parameters as you desire.

Use Instruction Manual for assembly instructions and Arduino coding.

Programming:

  1. Download & Install Arduino IDE: https://www.arduino.cc/

  2. Copy all libraries to C:\Users\user\Documents\Arduino\libraries (or wherever your library folder is installed):

  3. Finally open OTTO_smooth_criminal.ino code & upload to your Arduino Nano for dancing Otto mode.

  4. Try OTTO_avoid.ino for obstacle avoidance

More codes in https://github.com/OttoDIY/
You can use MBlock for simple an easy graphical programming

Otto builder group

Any problems printing or making or programming?
Join or create a topic in our group http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/ottodiy/

For battery power make sure to supply at least 6V and a maximum of 12V in the Vin input
suggested to try first and only program using the Mini USB cable to power your circuit from your computer or a USB socket.

If you want to add Bluetooth control with an APP try Otto DIY+ https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2398231

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Recommended to use a FDM 3D printer with PLA material.

You can print individually piece by piece to match the colors of the original design or optionally print all at the same time in an area of 14cm x 14cm.

Legs and Foot fitting

For almost all 3d printers is recommendable use the new version 04 .stl files to print, then you just use the plastic arm of the servo motors with some glue to assemble them together.

Designed using 123D Design (now thinkercad!)

Otto was inspired by another robot BoB the BiPed and programmed using code from Zowi.
CC-BY-SA

Otto's differences are in the assembled size (11cm x 7cm x12cm), cleaner integration of components and expressions. Using off the shelf and 3D printed parts, simple electronics connections (almost no welding required), and basic coding skills, you will be able to build your own cute Otto friend in as little as two hours!

Otto is designed using Autodesk 123D Design software (now thinkercad) you can modify it for customization or further improvements!
https://tinkercad.com/things/1kI624iowUR
NGSS CCSS

open source STEM We are collecting feedback from different workshop and schools around the world that are already using Otto in their classroom and depending of the openness of this educational places we want to publish as well, some people are teaching electronics explaining the connections with Fritzing and the physics behind, other code with Arduino then publish Github, other to create open source APPs in app inventor, other how to design 3d models accessories for Otto with tinkerCAD or Fusion 360, how to use 3D printers and so on. If you are interested to give feedback around this please message me ;)

Build your Own Otto Workshop But…Who is Otto? Otto is an interactive robot that anyone can make!
What can Otto do? Otto walks, dances, makes sounds and avoids obstacles
Why Is Otto special? Otto is completely open source, 3D printable, and Arduino compatible This is the opportunity to build and have your first robot.
First there will be a little introduction about Otto and the team behind, Second you will receive one Otto DIY kit including all tools you need to make this biped robot. And lastly you will follow the assembly instructions and you would be able to finish your new Otto robot and play. Includes one Otto DIY kit and all the tools to build it in 2-3 hours. No need technical knowledge, perfect for beginners and easy hackable for experts. Due small screws the workshops is recommend for 7+ years old, unless the children are accompanied by parents. Code your own Otto Ok so was fun to build now lets get into Otto's brain. By following the instructions will start to program your own robot by just modifying few lines of code, the simplicity of the function will help to easily jump into coding. Design your own robot Using TinkerCAD or Autodesk Fusion 360 or OpenSCAD (for more advance students) will be able to modify the source files or even recreate them to make you own robot and applied all the knowledge from the previous lessons. Customize, modify, remix and recreate your own Otto. then share to the world!

For a workshop Bring all list of electronic parts mentioned before and all 3d components of Otto printed. Take some extras of each parts specially servos they break easily. Is good to have some extra AA batteries and a soldering iron in case of accidents and further making. Print the instruction manual in A6 format and have them organize and ready for the class

comments.text:
I have no problems with spending a lot of time to get things running. That is indeed the fun of DIY. And I did spend a lot of time.
As explained, I considered this at first as a great project for my High-school students. But, although "Ottobot" is a very nice robot, there is a huge gap between the DIY Ottobot running an adapted Ottobot_criminal sketch or running a sketch with Bluetooth, Ultrasonic sensor, microphone etc.
Observing this difference is by no means critizising Cparrapa for what he has done. Why should I? I have two Ottobots walking around, and dancing. Very nice.
I solved the problem of the servo spines. Helas, this solution is not for High-School students. Also rewriting the entire code -which is what I am currently doing- is not within the reach of students.
That was what I tried to say. My apologies for my bad English.
comments.author: Mathteacher

comments.text:
Hi Teacher
have you seen the great update we did with legs, feet and code in github, now everything is much simple and easy. is it better than your solution?
How are your clases going?
We did workshops and the gap is pretty small.

Hi Paul
Looking forward for your makes pictures or videos here in thingiverse, also your code since we are also working on that. Some day we would be able to published as educational project

When I first discovered OttoBot I was very pleased since this seems to be the perfect small robot project for HighSchool students.
After two month of trying, I have put this project aside, being rather disappointed.
The 3D files are inaccurate. No way your servo spine will hold. You must improvize...
Small differences between different servo's from different suppliers cause great dimensional problems.
The basis code is straightforward. But anyone who wants Ottobot to respond to Ultrasonic Distance, or to Bluetooth signals is facing a substantial challenge. There is no documentation, you have to do reverse engineering to find out the pin layout for buzzer, buttons, Bluetooth, microphone. (Which is all on a dedicated board in the original Zowi)
You have to study the important osciilator routine thoroughly to understand how it functions. I am still puzzled...
Still, after spending many many hours, I wonder how to implement ultrasonic distance measurements? How to add a Bluetooth connection? The original code is full of delays.Delays are evil!
I was able to add a Bluetooth module, I renamed it to "Zowi" and the app reckognizes the connection. Than everything stops. How to proceed?
Yes, admitted, OttoBot Criminal shows pretty dance moves. But the OttoBot_ToDo program is an advanced piece of programming. Without detailed description and documentation not suitable for modification or even to get it running. This is not a HighSchool project.
comments.author: Mathteacher

comments.text: Without any prior experience, I was able to add bluetooth and four servos to an arduino and create an app to control them - in the space of a day. It isn't difficult to find the information if you use Google, YouTube and a bit of common sense. The 3D files are not inaccurate but maybe your printer or settings are. Don't use different servo's from those recommended. You don't need to reverse engineer anything. It's not difficult to use a spare pin and reference it in your code (IDE lesson 1) or if your'e using existing code it's simple enough to search it for pin assignments There is a huge, knowledgeable and helpful community all working towards developing these projects so your negative and unhelpful attitude it is really disappointing. If you are having such difficulty then might I suggest you start with something a little simpler.

With a little work, I added a RFM12B radio receiver module. So now I have an OttoBot which is moving under remote control.
To get enough space for this little shield, I had to slightly modify the Nano board. I had to remove some of the not used pins.
I really like these JeeLabs shields with a RFM12 Hope chip. Sending and receiving is very easy.

comments.text: Please re-read. You won't find any offensive language in my post, I'm not that sort of person. If you took offence at my post then that is different and a matter of perspective. People considering building Otto might read these posts and I'd hate for anyone to be put off by being given the impression that it's particularly complex. I've just completed a re-print of Otto's feet as my daughter wanted them in orange and I'm happy to report that the servos attached without any modification. I use Simply3D, printed with 1.75mm PLA @ 210 degrees. 0.15mm layer height, 3000 mm/min speed & 20% infill. Printed on an Anet A8. Happy Ottoing people!

author: FeedbackSoundCompany

title: Custom Closed Belt How To UPDATED

description.text:
I needed a custom sized GT2 Belt for my printer. Here is how I made one...

1 > Cut Belt to Specific length plus your desired overlap (I used six "belt humps")

2 > Cut belt in half ,laterally, along belt cords to desired overlap (use extremely sharp razor blade)

3 > Remove the front half of the belt on one end, the back half on the other

4 > Apply rubber cement to each end of belt

5 > wait 15 minutes

6 > Press ends together

7 > I'd wait several hours for glue to set up completely.

8 > Use Belt!

They are actually pretty strong when done. Enjoy.

EDIT - After prolonged use the stress on the thinnest part of the lap joint can stretch causing skips in operation. I found a new system for creating closed loop belts as follows.

1 > cut length of belt to desired size.

2 > cut second length of belt slightly longer than piece cut in step 1 (about 10mm longer).

3 > apply rubber cement to back side of both belt lengths.

4 > wait 10 - 15 minutes.

5 > press pieces together, starting by aligning the end of inside belt to middle of outer belt. (this allows for the most overlap, creating one solid belt, essentially.

6 > Pictures of double belt design has been added to the photos of this process.

I had to over size the ID by about 0.030" to compensate for my printer which prints a bit wide. If your printer is calibrated to true size, reduce the model by 2-3%.

This phone stand was created for an iPhone 5. It has a convenient hole for the charging cable to go through. It also has a hole for the earphone jack and a hole for the camera. This ties into the #MakerEdChallenge2 because I made this as part of an engineering project in my school. I have enjoyed creating things that can be used to help with other things. I finally bought a 3d printer for myself when I started the engineering class.
NOTE:
-For use with all IPhone 5 editions
-The stand shown in the pictures has since been updated for a better fit.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%
Your Printer should be able to print it in the orientation already set. You may also need a raft depending on your printer.
The assignment our teacher gave us was to create an object we could use every day. When I would charge my phone it would look messy so this seemed like a good solution that looked good.

To complete the #MakerEdChallenge2 it is necessary to have calipers that will help with getting specific measurements. For a teacher to complete a modeling portion of an engineering class it may take 2-3 weeks depending on student skill level and the complexity of the design. You will need to have some understanding of 3d modeling and basic math skills to make the stand. Any school with a 3d printer can do this because it encourages the students to build something that they could use and take home. To know that they actually made it makes having something like this more special.

description.text:
The standard HobbyKing Outlaw 180 comes with 23mm aluminum posts that screw into the legs with one screw. Well, the flight controller is slung under the frame so you can't remove the legs and the first time you land on one leg before the others they bend all out of shape.

These replace those posts with wider and stronger mounts with zip ties to spread the forces out. These should actually work on anything that needs about 23mm of lift (the thin cover of the flight controller is about 18-20 mm away from the bottom of the arms and has about 20mm wide arms (probably more as they are zip tied on but this was to handle the force of landing at a bit of an angle). There is a channel up the center to prevent fouling the motor wires.

Works a treat. When you fly like I do you hit a lot of planets. Didn't even manage to break a prop. Of course the carbon fiber props probably help.

Printer:

Turnigy Fabrikator Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I printed in Bamtack! PLA at 195, blue tape platform - only one at a time as I tend to get strings or rip pieces off the platform if I move more than about an inch between sections of a layer.

Cura slicer used.
Stock posts, straightened multiple times and starting to crack and the first of a set of new pads. A full set of pads.

Designed in Tinkercad.

Notes about the HobbyKing Outlaw 180 - Flaw as delivered

There is another flaw (beyond the dumb posts) with the Outlaw 180 as delivered by HobbyKing - the nylon 5" props that they are so proud of flex too much and hit the camera mount.

A set of carbon fiber 5" blades solved that problem.

I have a set of 4x4.5x3 nylon I want to try on it after I manage to finally break these props.

Just trying to keep it flying...

I use wheel Rollerblade size 100 mm. and aluminium Tube 10 mm. for frame

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount for v2.1 Camera

description.text:
The original design, of which this is a remix, did not allow the use
of the new 8 megapixel Raspberry Pi v2.1 Camera. The 2.1 camera,
although having the same basic circuit board dimensions, has surface
mount parts and a camera-circuit board cable that bulges off to the side.
In short, the original design would not fit the new camera. I revised the
design in Tinkercad. It will now work with the v2.1 camera and should
probably work with the original camera as well, although the fit may be
looser. I had to do some minor sanding on the backing plate to get it to fit.

description.text:
This was made to mount a Logitech Bluetooth audio adapter under the cabinets in my kitchen to connect phones to the speakers so I could play music while cooking, and it was easy to access for guests to pair.

Just print it as it is, and drop the adapter in from the top, with the power connection, and aux port facing out the largest opening. screw to whatever surface you like, and your're done! there is a bit of space between the bottom of the adapter and the bottom of the mount, this was intentional to let it breath a little bit, I wasn't sure how much heat this unit generates but I figured it wouldn't hurt to give it a little more space to breathe. If you'd like a tighter fit, feel free to modify the design or, shim it.

author: DMCL-GB-Avatar

print_settings.Notes:: All bolts should be printed in high infill settings to ensure rigidity of the bolts when securing them with the bolts

description.text:
This is the full printable version of the camera dolly and it is modular as well. Can be printed on small printers that has a max of 8cm^3 print volume.

The idea here is to make use of 3d printers that can make new items and this dolly also from a conventional (not so easy to source) parts.

This design are made to be fully modular style so that if one of the parts broken, you can just print that broken parts away without the need of printing a large object just to replace them.

https://youtu.be/oM_nrLxyOFw

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%+

Notes:

Just print the way it is.

All bolts should be printed in high infill settings to ensure rigidity of the bolts when securing them with the bolts

It is to optimize the plastic usage for printing these parts and reduce the consumption of supports needed during printing.

Not to mention about separate bolts designs, some slicer tools doesn't support individual infill settings so having them separate are crucial to make these model compatible with other slicer tools at the same time reduce the plastic consumption.

In overall, every aspect were taken into account during designing this project which is; rigidity, functionality, modular design and compatibility across different printers (big and small volume).

Fully Printable Camera Dolly

Making full use of 3d printer where 99% of them are 3d printed to make something without the need to source hard to find parts

Overview & Background

Learn:

  • A little bit of assemblies
  • Parts fitting of 3d printed object
  • How to make use of your surrounding
  • A bit of mechanical
  • Challenge of no supports needed
Objectives

Students will learn:

  • Modular designs
  • Making designs compatible across vast environments
  • Mechanical
  • 3D printed physics
Audiences

Age: 12 and above
Skills: Physics, Assemblies of 3d printed parts, Math

Subjects
  • Science
  • Mechanical
  • Math
  • Relativity
  • Physics
Skills Learned
  • Optimizing designs
  • Assemblies
  • Printed parts compatibility
  • Analysis
Lesson/Activity Duration

Just a mere of about 10 minutes of assemblies

Preparation

Only those printed parts and several Foam Double Sided Tape

Rubric & Assessment

Students are expected to make a mount for other devices such as:

  • Conventional camera mount (that requires screw directly)
  • Compatibility with several quick release plate from different tripods (different from the above)
  • Mounts for phones (adjustable are better to accommodate different phone size)

Without compromising the ability to rotate the device sideways after mounting them and ability to make the device to be tilted after mounted is a huge advantage to this project.

Please refer to the note below about incorporating your own mount to this project.

File name with "UNI"

These are the templates for those who wants to incorporate their own mount into this design without the need to replicate the whole thing again.

The "uni mount.stl" is the only thing you would want to incorporate your design to and the radius of the cylinder is 19mm. It has been extruded by 5mm more than the adapter to make it stand out so that you guys are able to just stick something on it with merging your designs with my "uni mount.stl"

BOM
  • Nut x 7
  • Wingnut x 2
  • Square bushing x 2
  • Adapter screw x 2
  • Axle screw x 2
  • Axle x 2
  • wheel x 4
  • Wheel nut x 4
  • End frame x 2
Prepping the wheel

Find any of your favorite foam double sided tape and wrap them all around the wheel.

Once the foam has been stick to the wheel, open the other side and slowly roll it on your hand or any surface to deplete the stickiness or glue of the outer side that has been exposed.

This is to create a small grip on the wheel when pushed.

Here's a pillow-block for the Robo3D R1 & R1+ using IGUS RJM-08 plastic bearings.

I haven't extensively tested it but it's working on my R1 right now (and it's super quiet!).

I printed mine in ABS... I wouldn't recommend PLA because it's so close to the heated bed but other types of filament which have a high melting point would probably work.

title: Lm8uu printable bearing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I designed this to use as a printable linear bearing. I designed it so, if the time came that i wanted to upgrade to a bigger bed then i could print the bearings. They were designed so, that i can spray silicon lightweight lube into them though the threads (inner grooves). I really don't like lm8uu bearings because they are made from a mix of rubber "horrible friction without lube" and ball bearings that can and will fall out if put on without an extra gentle touch. They were designed so that they would use less filament and be fast to print. This was accomplished with the twist on the inside. The 1st was a test and the 2nd another test the 3rd was the final draft or at least the one i printed out. It is really strong when i printed it out of nylon.

comments.text:
Thanks for sharing!
i made it in longer version 55mm - it replaces two set of 2x lm8uu in my heatbed platform :)
